COMPLEX: Côte-des-Neiges is a working-class neighborhood of Montreal, Quebec, Canada, situated at the geographic center of the Island of Montreal on the western slope of Mount Royal. The neighborhood is part of the borough Côte-des-Neiges–Notre-Dame-de-Grâce.

SECONDARY: Côte-des-Neiges is a working-class neighborhood in Montreal, Quebec, located at the center of the Island of Montreal on the western slope of Mount Royal. It is part of the borough Côte-des-Neiges–Notre-Dame-de-Grâce.
ADVANCED: Côte-des-Neiges is a working-class neighborhood in Montreal, Quebec, located at the geographic center of the Island of Montreal on the western slope of Mount Royal and is part of the borough Côte-des-Neiges–Notre-Dame-de-Grâce.

COMPLEX: In the early 13th century, when the growth of communities of scholars (universities) in Paris and other major cities led to an expansion and streamlining of the book-production trade, punctuation was rationalized by assigning Alcuin's stroke-over-dot specifically to interrogatives; by this time, the stroke was more sharply curved and can easily be recognized as the modern question mark.
ELEMENTARY: In the early 1200s, cities like Paris grew many schools and changed the way books were made. They also changed punctuation by using a special mark on questions that looks like our modern question mark.
SECONDARY: In the early 13th century, as scholarly communities grew in major cities like Paris, the book-production trade expanded and punctuation was changed by assigning a specific mark to questions; this mark eventually became the modern question mark.
ADVANCED: In the early 13th century, as scholarly communities in cities like Paris streamlined book production, punctuation was reformed by designating Alcuin's stroke-over-dot for interrogatives—a mark that evolved into the modern question mark.
